March 2, 1975: Fiction
CENTENNIAL, by James Michener.  (Random House, $12.50.) Dioramic historical
novel covering the land and people around Centennial, Colo.
THE SEVEN-PER-CENT SOLUTION, edited by Nicholas Meyer.  (Dutton, $6.95.)
Droll resurrection of Sherlock Holmes, in which he kicks cocaine, foils a grand plot
against world peace.
SOMETHING HAPPENED, by Joseph Heller. (Knopf, $10.)  A man's obsession
with the past: a revelation of a type and a time.
LADY, by Thomas Tryon.  (Knopf, $7.95.) Intimations of evil about her that are
slow in revealing themselves.
THE EBONY TOWER, by John Fowles. (Little, Brown, $7.95.) Elegantly turned
stories that explore eros and the muse, among other matters.
THE PIRATE, by Harold Robbins.  (Simon & Schuster, $8.95.) Middle Eastern
melodrama laced with sex, money and power.
TINKER, TAILOR, SOLDIER, SPY, by John le Carr√©. (Knopf, $7.95.) Thinking
man's spy story about the search for a Soviet "mole."
HARLEQUIN, by Morris West. (Morrow, $7.95.) Business-world thriller involving
corporate espionage and other dirty tricks.
BLACK SUNDAY, by Thomas Harris (Putnam's, $7.95.) Bludgeoning, topical
thriller about plot to blow up the Super Bowl.
THE DOGS OF WAR, by Frederick Forsyth. (Viking, $7.95.) Authenticity is the
main virtue of the thriller about an African coup d'etat.
March 2, 1975
Non-Fiction
THE BERMUDA TRIANGLE, by Charles Berlitz. (Doubleday, $7.95.) Uncritical
theorizing about allegedly mysterious ship-plane disappearances.
THE PALACE GUARD, by Dan Rather and Gary Paul Gates.  (Harper & Row,
$8.95.) Juicy anecdotes about the Nixon White House; debatable theorizing.
STRICTLY SPEAKING, by Edwin Newman. (Bobbs-Merrill, $7.95.) A plea for
good English, with a plenitude of funny-horrible examples.
ALL THINGS BRIGHT AND BEAUTIFUL, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's Press,
$8.95.) Pleasant memoirs of a Yorkshire veterinarian.
THE ULTRA SECRET, by F.W. Winterbotham. (Harper & Row, $8.95.) The
ultimate World War II secret -- how the British broke the German code.
HELTER SKELTER, by Vincent Bugliosi with Curt Gentry. (Norton, $10.)
Authoritative account of the Manson family murders and trial.
THE BANKERS, by Martin Mayer. (Weybright and Talley, $15.) Comprehensive,
fact-laden look at banking, lacking in daily-life relevance.
TALES OF POWER, by Carlos Castaneda.  (Simon & Schuster, $7.95.) How to
remember the things you'd rather not forget.
THE MEMORY BOOK, by Harry Lorayne and Jerry Lucas. (Stein & Day, $7.95.)
How to remember the things you'd rather not forget.
A BRIDGE TOO FAR, by Cornelius Ryan. (Simon & Schuster, $12.50.) A
disastrous Allied action in World War II, vividly retold.
